title: Of Rats and Men
description: Rats. Love 'em or hate 'em, (though you probably hate 'em), they're part of our world. And during the pandemic, they've been out in full force: fewer humans outdoors means more space for rats. And it turns out, they're a lot like us: They've colonized the whole planet; they're incredibly adaptable; they go wherever the resources are. And, they share one-fourth of our genome—so when you're looking in the mirror, you're kinda seeing a rat staring back at you. So for this episode, we dove into the history of our rodent doppelgängers. What we found was a story that spans thousands of years and nearly every continent on Earth, from the fields of ancient Mongolia to the palaces of Victorian England to the laboratories of 20th century Maryland... and probably to a burrow near you.

itunes:title: Of Rats and Men
itunes:author: NPR
itunes:summary: They might be pests, but we share a lot of genes with rats. In this episode of Throughline, we explore the history of rats — which tells us a lot about our own.
itunes:subtitle: They might be pests, but we share a lot of genes with rats. In this episode of Throughline, we explore the history of rats — which tells us a lot about our own.
